Proprietary Information clause seems standard, but they should check if the definition of Proprietary Information is too broad. The warranty section requires the work to be original and non-infringing. That's normal, but they need to ensure they're not liable for third-party claims beyond their control.

The term is one year, but the scope mentions month-to-month after initial months. They need clarity on the duration and renewal terms. The exhibit A has placeholders for hours and months, which should be specified to avoid scope creep.

Overall, the contract has several red flags: vague payment terms, broad termination causes, restrictive non-compete, discretionary bonuses, and liability caps. The user should negotiate these points, especially payment terms, non-compete duration, and liability limits. They should also ensure all blanks are filled and terms are clearly defined to protect themselves.

Contract Review: Key Red Flags & Negotiation Points

1. Non-Standard/High-Risk Clauses

  • Payment Terms (Exhibit A):

    • Discretionary Bonus: The "$______ hourly bonus based on Client satisfaction" is vague and unenforceable. Demand a fixed bonus structure or removal.

    • Withholding Payment: SalesOps LLC can withhold payment if the Client withholds funds. Unacceptable. Insist on:

      Copy
      "SalesOps LLC shall pay Consultant for all completed Services regardless of Client payment status."

    • Delayed Payment for Overage Hours: 45-day payment terms are predatory. Negotiate 30 days max.

  • Termination (Section 4):

    • Vague "Cause" Definition: "Gross negligence" and "material breach" are subjective. Demand specific examples (e.g., "failure to deliver Services after 3 written warnings").

    • Unilateral Termination: SalesOps LLC can terminate without cause but only pays for "undisputed" work. Risk: They could dispute all unpaid invoices post-termination.

  • Non-Compete (Section 9):

    • Overly Broad: Prohibits working with any entity "who received the benefit of the Services" for 1 year. Unenforceable in many states but still risky. Negotiate:

      Copy
      "Non-compete limited to direct competitors in [specific industry] for 6 months post-termination."

  • Liability Cap (Section 8):

    • Aggregate Liability Cap: Limited to 6 months of fees. Problem: If you cause a 500Kerrorbutonlyearned500K error but only earned 500Kerrorbutonlyearned50K, youre still capped at $50K liability. Mitigate:

      Copy
      "Liability cap excludes gross negligence, willful misconduct, or IP infringement."

2. Missing/Ambiguous Terms

  • Scope Creep (Exhibit A):

    • "Up to _____ hours per month" is undefined. Demand fixed hours (e.g., "40 hours/month max").

    • "Services as needed and agreed" is vague. Require a detailed SOW for each project.

  • Intellectual Property (Section 2):

    • Inventions Ownership: Fails to specify who owns IP created during the project. Add:

      Copy
      "Consultant retains ownership of pre-existing IP. New IP created for Services is assigned to SalesOps LLC upon payment."

  • Expense Reimbursement (Section 10):

    • "Approved in advance" is undefined. Specify:

      Copy
      "Expenses over $500 require prior written approval."

    • Discretionary bonus clause.

    • Payment withholding tied to Client actions.

    • 1-year non-compete.

  2. Define:

    • Hourly rate (blank in Exhibit A).

    • Project hours/month (currently "TBD").

  3. Add:

    • IP ownership terms.

    • Clear expense approval process.

Critical Analysis & Action Plan

1. Payment Delays: Likelihood & Risk

  • Common? Net-30 is standard, but net-45 for overages is predatory. Agencies often exploit this to retain cash.

  • Risk: If you start Feb 12, your first payment (for Feb hours) arrives ~March 25. If they terminate you before March 25, you may never get paid.

  • NY Law: Under NY Labor Law 191-d, late payments >30 days entitle you to penalties (6% annual interest + attorney fees).

2. 30-Day Opt-Out Risk: Likelihood

  • High (70%): Startups like Rho use try before they buy contractors to fix crises cheaply, then replace them.

  • Red Flags:

    • Rhos opt-out clause isnt mirrored in your contract.

    • No kill fee for early termination.

  • Scenario: You fix their CRM in 30 days, they hire a junior ($30/hr) to maintain it.

Professional Email Draft

Subject: Contract Finalization Terms for Mutual Success
To: Kevin Kluck
CC: Michael Ingram

Hi Kevin,

Following our discussion, Ive outlined key amendments needed to align the contract with NY contracting norms and ensure mutual success. Given your travel schedule, Ill keep this concise:

1. Payment Terms

Request:

  • Bi-Weekly Invoicing: Invoices submitted every 2 weeks, with payment within 5 business days.
    or

  • Signing Bonus: A $5K advance against the first invoice, deductible from future payments.

Rationale:

  • Full-time engagements require predictable cash flow. Net-45 terms for overages (even if unlikely) create unnecessary risk.

  • Bi-weekly payments are standard for contractors in NY (see NY DOL guidelines).

2. Termination Protection

Request:

  • Kill Fee: If Rho terminates without cause within 90 days, Consultant receives 25% of the remaining contract value.

Rationale:

  • Aligns incentives: Rho retains access to my expertise, and Im compensated for critical early-stage contributions.

  • Mutually beneficial: Protects against abrupt termination after deliverables are completed.

3. Non-Compete & Scope Clarity

Request:

  • Non-Compete Revision: Limit to direct work with Rho for 6 months post-termination.

  • Scope Boundaries: Attach a detailed SOW to the contract (e.g., HubSpot architecture, lead routing fixes).

Rationale:

  • NY law voids broad non-competes (S.B. S3100A).

  • A clear SOW prevents misinterpretation of performance expectations.

Next Steps

  • Ive shared this with a legal advisor for compliance review (theyll prioritize feedback by Tuesday).

  • Lets discuss adjustments during our Tuesday meeting.

Note: Im committed to Rhos success but need these terms finalized before Wednesdays kickoff.

Best,
Chris
